title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 19 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Chronicles chapter 19 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 19 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Chronicles Chapter 19.

questions.question: Where did Jehoshaphat return to in peace according to 2 Chronicles 19?
questions.correctAnswer: Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Verse 1 states Jehoshaphat returned to his house in peace to Jerusalem.

questions.question: Who met Jehoshaphat and rebuked him for helping the ungodly?
questions.correctAnswer: Jehu the son of Hanani
questions.explanation: Verse 2 says Jehu the son of Hanani the seer went out to meet Jehoshaphat and spoke to him.

questions.question: According to 2 Chronicles 19:3, what good thing was found in Jehoshaphat?
questions.correctAnswer: He took away the groves
questions.explanation: Verse 3 states Jehoshaphat took away the groves and prepared his heart to seek God.

questions.question: From where to where did Jehoshaphat go out among the people to bring them back to the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: From Beersheba to Mount Ephraim
questions.explanation: Verse 4 states Jehoshaphat went out from Beersheba to Mount Ephraim to bring the people back to God.

questions.question: What did Jehoshaphat set in the land throughout all the fenced cities of Judah?
questions.correctAnswer: Judges
questions.explanation: Verse 5 says he set judges in the land city by city.

questions.question: Who are judges to judge for, according to Jehoshaphat's instruction?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 6 instructs judges to judge not for man but for the LORD who is with them.

questions.question: What did Jehoshaphat say there is no respect of with the LORD our God?
questions.correctAnswer: Persons
questions.explanation: Verse 7 says the LORD does not show respect of persons.

questions.question: In Jerusalem, Jehoshaphat set Levites, priests, and the chief of the fathers of Israel for what purpose?
options: Judgment of the LORD and controversies
questions.correctAnswer: Judgment of the LORD and controversies
questions.explanation: Verse 8 explains they were set for the judgment of the LORD and controversies when they returned to Jerusalem.

questions.question: How did Jehoshaphat charge the judges and priests to act?
options: In the fear of the LORD, faithfully, and with a perfect heart
questions.correctAnswer: In the fear of the LORD, faithfully, and with a perfect heart
questions.explanation: Verse 9 states his charge was to act in the fear of the LORD faithfully and with a perfect heart.

questions.question: True or False: Jehoshaphat warned that if the brethren trespass against the LORD, wrath would come upon them.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 10 warns that trespassing against the LORD would bring wrath upon them and their brethren.

questions.question: Who is appointed over all matters of the LORD according to 2 Chronicles 19?
questions.correctAnswer: Amariah the chief priest
questions.explanation: Verse 11 names Amariah the chief priest as over all matters of the LORD.

questions.question: Who was ruler of the house of Judah for all the king's matters?
questions.correctAnswer: Zebadiah the son of Ishmael
questions.explanation: Verse 11 states Zebadiah son of Ishmael was the ruler of the house of Judah for king's matters.

questions.question: True or False: Jehoshaphat commanded judges to deal courageously because the LORD would be with the good.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 11 encourages dealing courageously, promising the LORD will be with the good.

questions.question: True or False: Jehoshaphat took away the groves from the land but did not prepare his heart to seek God.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 3 states that Jehoshaphat both took away the groves and prepared his heart to seek God.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 2 Chronicles 19:6: 'Take heed what ye do: for ye judge not for man, but for the ______, who is with you in the judgment.'
questions.correctAnswer: LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 6 clearly states the judges judge for the LORD who is with them in judgment.

medium.title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 19 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Chronicles Chapter 19 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with favoritism at work. Based on 2 Chronicles 19, what biblical principle would you share about judgment and fairness?
options: Judges must show respect of persons and accept gifts
Judges should judge for man, not for the LORD
Judges must not show partiality or accept bribes
Judges can judge based on personal opinions
questions.correctAnswer: Judges must not show partiality or accept bribes
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 19:6-7 teaches that judges judge not for man but for the LORD, and that there is no respect of persons nor taking of gifts with God, emphasizing fairness and impartiality.

questions.question: How does 2 Chronicles 19 encourage believers to respond when dealing with disputes among brethren?
options: Warn them to avoid trespassing against the LORD
Favor one side to maintain order
questions.correctAnswer: Warn them to avoid trespassing against the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 10 instructs judges to warn brethren not to trespass against the LORD so that wrath may be avoided, emphasizing responsibility in handling disputes.

questions.question: Jehoshaphat set judges throughout Judah and instructed them to judge in what spirit?
options: With fear of the LORD and faithfulness
questions.correctAnswer: With fear of the LORD and faithfulness
questions.explanation: Jehoshaphat commanded judges to act in the fear of the LORD, faithfully, and with a perfect heart as described in verses 6, 7, and 9.

questions.question: A believer wants to strengthen their family spiritually. Based on Jehoshaphat's example in 2 Chronicles 19, what practical step should they take?
options: Set their heart to seek God and remove evil influences
Depend on others to lead their family
questions.correctAnswer: Set their heart to seek God and remove evil influences
questions.explanation: Verse 3 highlights Jehoshaphat's preparation of his heart to seek God and removal of groves, showing the importance of intentional spiritual discipline at home.

questions.question: What does 2 Chronicles 19 teach about courage in leadership and decision-making?
options: Leaders should deal courageously and trust the LORD will be with the good
Leaders should avoid difficult decisions to keep peace
Leaders must rely on their own strength alone
Leaders should favor the powerful to maintain influence
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders should deal courageously and trust the LORD will be with the good
questions.explanation: Verse 11 encourages courage in dealing with matters and assures that the LORD is with those who do good.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Chronicles 19, Jehoshaphat was rebuked for helping the ungodly and loving those who hate the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 2 records Jehu the seer rebuking Jehoshaphat for helping ungodly people and loving those who hate the LORD, which brought wrath upon him.

questions.question: How does 2 Chronicles 19 model the importance of spiritual leadership in the church?
options: Jehoshaphat appointed Levites and priests for judgment and controversies
Jehoshaphat left spiritual matters to the people
Jehoshaphat only focused on military leadership
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoshaphat appointed Levites and priests for judgment and controversies
questions.explanation: Verse 8 shows Jehoshaphat setting Levites, priests, and chief fathers for the judgment of the LORD, emphasizing godly leadership in the community.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to show partiality at work. According to 2 Chronicles 19, what should they remember about God's judgment?
options: God shows no respect of persons and no acceptance of bribes
God favors the wealthy and powerful
questions.correctAnswer: God shows no respect of persons and no acceptance of bribes
questions.explanation: Verses 6 and 7 emphasize that God’s judgment is impartial and free from corruption or favoritism.

questions.question: What does Jehoshaphat’s action of removing groves from the land teach us about personal holiness and obedience?
options: Removing idols and evil influences is part of seeking God sincerely
Idols are acceptable if they bring peace
Obedience is optional in difficult times
Personal holiness is only about external rituals
questions.correctAnswer: Removing idols and evil influences is part of seeking God sincerely
questions.explanation: Verse 3 praises Jehoshaphat for taking away groves and preparing his heart to seek God, showing obedience and commitment to holiness.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "And Jehoshaphat dwelt at Jerusalem: and he went out again through the people from ________ to mount Ephraim, and brought them back unto the LORD God of their fathers."
questions.correctAnswer: Beersheba
questions.explanation: Verse 4 states Jehoshaphat went through the people from Beersheba to mount Ephraim, calling them back to the LORD, demonstrating evangelistic zeal.

questions.question: According to 2 Chronicles 19, what is the role of Amariah the chief priest and Zebadiah the ruler in the kingdom?
options: Amariah oversees matters of the LORD; Zebadiah manages king’s matters
Both serve as royal advisors without specific duties
questions.correctAnswer: Amariah oversees matters of the LORD; Zebadiah manages king’s matters
questions.explanation: Verse 11 assigns Amariah over all matters of the LORD and Zebadiah over king’s matters, illustrating godly order in leadership.

questions.question: True or False: Jehoshaphat’s return to Jerusalem was marked by peace and spiritual renewal.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 1 records Jehoshaphat’s peaceful return home, and verses 3-4 describe spiritual renewal through seeking God and calling people back to Him.

questions.question: What biblical virtue is emphasized when Jehoshaphat charges judges to act with a perfect heart and fear of the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Integrity and reverence
questions.explanation: Verse 9 highlights acting faithfully and with a perfect heart in the fear of the LORD, underscoring integrity and reverence as vital virtues.

questions.question: A believer is facing temptation to compromise on honesty at work. Based on Jehoshaphat’s example, what attitude should they adopt?
options: Trust in God and maintain honesty as judgment is from the LORD
Follow the crowd to avoid conflict
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God and maintain honesty as judgment is from the LORD
questions.explanation: Verses 6-7 emphasize judging and acting with the LORD’s presence in mind, encouraging believers to maintain honesty and integrity.

questions.question: How does 2 Chronicles 19 illustrate the importance of spiritual accountability in community leadership?
options: Jehoshaphat appointed Levites and priests for judgment and charged them to act faithfully
Jehoshaphat ignored spiritual matters in leadership
Leaders were told to act based on personal benefit
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoshaphat appointed Levites and priests for judgment and charged them to act faithfully
questions.explanation: Verses 8-9 show Jehoshaphat entrusting spiritual leaders to oversee judgment and controversies with faithfulness and fear of the LORD.

hard.title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 19 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Chronicles Chapter 19.

questions.question: What was Jehoshaphat's initial action after returning to Jerusalem according to 2 Chronicles 19?
options: He returned to his house in peace
He built altars to the LORD
He called for a national fast
questions.correctAnswer: He returned to his house in peace
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 19:1 states that Jehoshaphat returned to his house in peace to Jerusalem, marking a peaceful return from battle or journey.

questions.question: Who confronted Jehoshaphat about helping the ungodly, and what was the nature of the rebuke?
options: Elijah the prophet, warning of drought
Jehu the son of Hanani, declaring wrath from the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Jehu the son of Hanani, declaring wrath from the LORD
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 19:2 shows that Jehu the son of Hanani confronted Jehoshaphat, questioning why he helped the ungodly and warning of God's wrath as a result.

questions.question: Despite the rebuke, what positive action of Jehoshaphat was acknowledged?
options: He took away the groves and sought God
questions.correctAnswer: He took away the groves and sought God
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 19:3 acknowledges that Jehoshaphat removed idolatrous groves and prepared his heart to seek God, highlighting his sincerity despite his faults.

questions.question: Jehoshaphat's judicial reforms included appointing judges throughout Judah. What cities did he focus on?
options: All the fenced cities of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: All the fenced cities of Judah
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 19:5 specifies that Jehoshaphat set judges in all the fenced cities of Judah, indicating a focus on fortified urban centers for justice.

questions.question: According to 2 Chronicles 19, for whom were the judges supposed to judge—not for man, but for whom?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 19:6 instructs judges to judge not for man but for the LORD who is with them in judgment, emphasizing divine authority behind justice.

questions.question: Jehoshaphat warned the judges to act with fear of the LORD because there is no what with God?
options: Iniquity, respect of persons, nor taking of gifts
questions.correctAnswer: Iniquity, respect of persons, nor taking of gifts
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 19:7 declares that the LORD has no iniquity, partiality, or bribery, underscoring impartial and just judgment.

questions.question: In Jerusalem, Jehoshaphat appointed Levites and priests for what specific purpose?
options: To sing praises in the temple
To instruct the people in warfare
For the judgment of the LORD and controversies
questions.correctAnswer: For the judgment of the LORD and controversies
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 19:8 shows Jehoshaphat appointed Levites and priests to judge matters of the LORD and resolve controversies, indicating a religious judiciary.

questions.question: What two qualities did Jehoshaphat charge the judges to have when executing judgment?
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness and a perfect heart
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 19:9 commands judges to act in the fear of the LORD faithfully and with a perfect heart, emphasizing integrity and sincerity.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jehoshaphat instructed the judges to warn the people so they would not trespass against the LORD, for if they do, _____ will come upon them.
questions.correctAnswer: wrath
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 19:10 warns that trespassing against the LORD brings wrath upon the people and judges, highlighting the serious consequences of disobedience.

questions.question: Who was appointed as the chief priest over all matters of the LORD according to 2 Chronicles 19?
questions.correctAnswer: Amariah
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 19:11 states Amariah the chief priest is over the judges in all matters of the LORD, indicating his religious leadership role.

questions.question: True or False: Zebadiah, son of Ishmael, was appointed to oversee all king's matters in Judah.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 19:11 identifies Zebadiah son of Ishmael as the ruler over the house of Judah for all the king's matters, confirming his administrative role.

questions.question: Which literary device is evident in Jehoshaphat's judicial instructions emphasizing no respect of persons or taking of gifts?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 19:7 uses parallelism by listing 'no iniquity, nor respect of persons, nor taking of gifts' to emphasize impartial justice, a hallmark of Hebrew poetry.

questions.question: How does Jehoshaphat’s reform in setting judges relate typologically to New Testament teachings on judgment?
options: It foreshadows Christ as the ultimate judge
It predicts the fall of Jerusalem
It symbolizes the separation of Jews and Gentiles
It represents the building of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows Christ as the ultimate judge
questions.explanation: Jehoshaphat’s emphasis on judging for the LORD (2 Chronicles 19:6) typologically points to Christ’s role as the righteous judge in the New Testament (e.g., John 5:22).

questions.question: In the cultural context of the ancient Near East, why was the removal of groves significant in Jehoshaphat’s reforms?
options: Groves were centers for pagan worship
Groves were used for royal hunting
Groves produced sacred oil for anointing
questions.correctAnswer: Groves were centers for pagan worship
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 19:3 notes Jehoshaphat removed groves, which were associated with idolatrous worship practices, signaling religious purification in line with Israelite monotheism.

questions.question: What theme in 2 Chronicles 19 is consistent with the Deuteronomic emphasis found elsewhere in the Hebrew Bible?
options: The centrality of Jerusalem as the sole worship site
The fear of the LORD and just governance
The establishment of a priestly monarchy
questions.correctAnswer: The fear of the LORD and just governance
questions.explanation: The emphasis in 2 Chronicles 19:6-7 on fearing the LORD and impartial justice reflects the Deuteronomic theme of covenantal obedience and social justice.

theological.title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 19 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Chronicles Chapter 19 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was Jehoshaphat's attitude towards the ungodly, as rebuked by Jehu the seer?
questions.correctAnswer: He helped and loved them
questions.explanation: Jehu rebuked Jehoshaphat for helping the ungodly and loving those who hate the LORD (2 Chronicles 19:2). This reflects the biblical teaching that God's people must not align themselves with ungodliness (Psalm 1:1; 2 Corinthians 6:14).

questions.question: Despite the rebuke, what good thing did Jehoshaphat do that was recognized by God?
options: He took away the groves and prepared his heart to seek God
He built many altars to foreign gods
He made alliances with pagan kings
He ignored the Law of Moses
questions.correctAnswer: He took away the groves and prepared his heart to seek God
questions.explanation: Jehoshaphat was commended for removing idolatrous groves and preparing his heart to seek God (2 Chronicles 19:3), which aligns with biblical calls to repentance and wholehearted devotion (Deuteronomy 6:5; Psalm 119:2).

questions.question: What was the scope of Jehoshaphat's judicial reforms?
options: Throughout all the fenced cities of Judah, city by city
questions.correctAnswer: Throughout all the fenced cities of Judah, city by city
questions.explanation: Jehoshaphat appointed judges throughout all the fortified cities of Judah (2 Chronicles 19:5), demonstrating a comprehensive judicial reform consistent with God's law governing justice for all people (Deuteronomy 16:18; Proverbs 31:9).

questions.question: According to Jehoshaphat, for whom do the judges ultimately judge?
options: For the LORD who is with you in judgment
questions.correctAnswer: For the LORD who is with you in judgment
questions.explanation: Jehoshaphat instructed judges that they judge not for man but for the LORD who is with them (2 Chronicles 19:6), highlighting divine accountability in justice, consistent with biblical teaching on God's sovereignty over judgment (Psalm 82:1; James 4:12).

questions.question: What key principles did Jehoshaphat emphasize judges must observe?
options: Fear of the LORD, no iniquity, no respect of persons, and no taking of gifts
questions.correctAnswer: Fear of the LORD, no iniquity, no respect of persons, and no taking of gifts
questions.explanation: Jehoshaphat urged judges to fear the LORD and to avoid iniquity, partiality, and bribery (2 Chronicles 19:7), consistent with the biblical injunctions for righteous judgment (Exodus 23:3; Deuteronomy 16:19; Proverbs 17:23).

questions.question: Whom did Jehoshaphat appoint in Jerusalem to handle judgments and controversies?
options: Levites, priests, and chief fathers of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Levites, priests, and chief fathers of Israel
questions.explanation: Jehoshaphat set Levites, priests, and chief fathers in Jerusalem for the judgment of the LORD and controversies (2 Chronicles 19:8), reflecting the biblical role of the Levites and priests as mediators of divine law (Numbers 18:7; Deuteronomy 17:9).

questions.question: What qualities did Jehoshaphat charge those judging in the fear of the LORD to exhibit?
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness and a perfect heart
questions.explanation: He instructed judges to act faithfully and with a perfect heart in the fear of the LORD (2 Chronicles 19:9), emphasizing sincerity and integrity in judgment consistent with biblical ethics (Psalm 101:2; 1 Samuel 16:7).

questions.question: What types of cases were the judges expected to warn the people about to prevent wrath upon themselves and their brethren?
options: Cases involving blood, law, commandment, statutes, and judgments
questions.correctAnswer: Cases involving blood, law, commandment, statutes, and judgments
questions.explanation: Jehoshaphat commanded judges to warn against trespassing the LORD in matters of blood, law, commandment, statutes, and judgments (2 Chronicles 19:10), reflecting biblical concern for justice, holiness, and covenant obedience (Leviticus 19:15; Deuteronomy 19:16-21).

questions.question: Who was appointed chief priest over all matters of the LORD during Jehoshaphat's reforms?
questions.correctAnswer: Amariah
questions.explanation: Amariah was appointed chief priest over all matters of the LORD (2 Chronicles 19:11), emphasizing the priestly leadership in spiritual and judicial affairs as prescribed in the Law (Leviticus 10:10; Ezra 7:25).

questions.question: What role did Zebadiah, son of Ishmael, have in Jehoshaphat's judicial system?
options: Ruler of the house of Judah for all the king's matters
questions.correctAnswer: Ruler of the house of Judah for all the king's matters
questions.explanation: Zebadiah was appointed ruler of the house of Judah for all the king's matters (2 Chronicles 19:11), showing the integration of royal administration with judicial processes in alignment with biblical governance (1 Kings 4:3; Nehemiah 5:14).

questions.question: What did Jehoshaphat encourage the judges and officers to do in their duties?
options: Deal courageously, trusting the LORD with the good
Delegate all decisions to the king
questions.correctAnswer: Deal courageously, trusting the LORD with the good
questions.explanation: Jehoshaphat exhorted judges and officers to deal courageously, with the assurance that the LORD would be with the good (2 Chronicles 19:11), aligning with biblical exhortations to righteous boldness (Joshua 1:9; Psalm 27:14).

questions.question: What does Jehoshaphat's judicial reform imply about God's attribute of justice?
options: God requires impartial and righteous judgment without bribery
God endorses favoritism for the powerful
questions.correctAnswer: God requires impartial and righteous judgment without bribery
questions.explanation: Jehoshaphat emphasized no respect of persons and no taking of gifts (2 Chronicles 19:7), revealing God's attribute of perfect justice and impartiality (Deuteronomy 10:17; Proverbs 28:21; Acts 10:34).

questions.question: How does Jehoshaphat’s removal of the groves relate to the doctrine of idolatry?
options: It signifies a rejection of false worship and loyalty to the one true God
It indicates tolerance of all religious practices
It shows acceptance of pagan gods
It means building more altars for other gods
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies a rejection of false worship and loyalty to the one true God
questions.explanation: By taking away the groves (idolatrous sites), Jehoshaphat demonstrated fidelity to God alone (2 Chronicles 19:3), consistent with biblical calls to exclusive worship of Yahweh (Exodus 20:3-5; Isaiah 44:6).

questions.question: What theological principle about human judgment is taught by the fact that judges judge for the LORD and not for man?
options: Human judgment must reflect divine justice and accountability before God
Human judgment is independent of divine authority
Judges should prioritize human opinion over God's law
Judgment is a matter of personal preference
questions.correctAnswer: Human judgment must reflect divine justice and accountability before God
questions.explanation: Jehoshaphat's instruction that judges judge for the LORD (2 Chronicles 19:6) affirms that all human judgment is accountable to God, consistent with biblical teaching that God is the ultimate judge (Ecclesiastes 12:14; Hebrews 4:13).

questions.question: What is the eschatological significance of warning brethren not to trespass against the LORD in judicial matters?
options: It prevents divine wrath and aligns with final judgment accountability
It promotes human autonomy over divine law
questions.correctAnswer: It prevents divine wrath and aligns with final judgment accountability
questions.explanation: Warning brethren not to trespass against the LORD (2 Chronicles 19:10) prefigures the final judgment where all must give account (Romans 14:12; 2 Corinthians 5:10), showing the seriousness of covenant obedience.
